item.title: Welcome and hello!
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded: My name is Grace Breedlove. Yes, that's my honest-to-blog name, not some hippie moniker I just made up. I'm here in the blog world, because I like to talk. A lot. I have a big smile, a big personality and big opinions. I'm here to talk about yoga, travel, Buddhism, anarchism,  food, feminism, gratitude, wine and sunshine, and to meet people who are ready to jump into life with both feet. I want to know all the other dynamic, crazy weirdos who refuse to believe the nay-sayers, those who are changing the world and saving lives, those who live larger than life prescribed, because they can't stand to do anything else. I believe in the old adage, "Iron sharpens iron." I get my life's energy from hob-nobbing with those amazing people who are hungry like I am, unencumbered by airs or inefficient banalities, ready to suck the marrow out of life and bless their corner of the world with beauty and efficiency. I am not a minimalist or a martyr on the altar of self-mortification. Been there, done that, not my bag. I do live simply and find pleasure in the inexpensive gems of life, but I certainly don't deny myself those simple trappings that facilitate comfort and joy. I don't have the average roots of charmed privilege of those among my generation whose parents followed the rules. Though now I find myself at the weird and unexpected intersection of a fortuitous marriage, a dream job and the most perfect locale to call home, be sure that I grew up on the bare bones characterizing the American poverty line. I spend every day now blissed out and excited, surveying my life situation, asking aloud, "How did I possibly end up here?!"  I won't lie to you; it was a dark road, a sad, lonely, often hopeless road, the trials of which are written on my body from my piercing eyes to my self-injury scars to my cellulite. What always got me through those dark times, of which I will surely expound upon in this blog, were the ancient art of yoga and the constant rising and setting of the sun. I was blessed to be born with an insatiable curiosity about the world, a gnawing hunger to know everything about the human experience, a desperate need to know, as a child, that there was a different way to be. In my pre-adolescence, it was that curiosity that lead me to stumble upon a book on tantric yoga, a chance meeting that surely saved my psyche and my life. Then there is the sun, oh the sun! How I understand the urge of animistic cultures throughout time to personify and worship the sun as creator and destroyer, allegory for life, death and the life beyond. The sure constant of circuitous patterns, guaranteed until the sun turns supernova, comforts me and has comforted me always through the most tumultuous and horrific experiences of my young life. So thus, above all else, I am a solar-powered yogi. I'm ready to be fully honest and raw with you, my dear reader and soon friend. I hope you'll join me in a revolution of honesty, subversion, beauty, bliss and adventure. Thank you for stopping by.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I love your new page/look! Thank you for your humanitarian work and for reminding us of so many facts we may overlook every day.
Love and Peace Leah

item.title: Do you want to hear my story?
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_35" align="alignleft" width="200" caption="Me and a sweet boy named Kien. Hanoi, Vietnam, May 2010"][/caption] Here is the gods' honest truth: my goals and dreams are exceptional only in context. On the outset, they seem dull and, dare I say, normal, but let me explain. So much of what I read, what inspire me, are the extremely interesting escapades of my lovely friends and colleagues who have broken out of the norms of their middle-class American upbringings to set out on contextually bizarre and wonderful paths, choices that have truly required courage to be so different. I am the opposite. My ultimate goals are to own a home, stay married to the same guy for the rest of my life, adopt two or three kids, make sure those kids feel safe and loved, make a living doing whatever I damn well please and start a small non-profit building toilets and spreading public health education where they are needed throughout Southeast Asia. Terribly unremarkable in comparison to the lofty achievements of my contemporaries. Startlingly normal. Let me start at the beginning. I grew up poor. Very poor. A level of Western poverty I have only found admitted to in the blog-o-sphere by Dave at The Longest Way Home. Not only was there poverty, but there was addiction in my home, as well as spiritual abuse on account of my parents' involvement in a once dangerous cult. The cult broke my parents. My mother eventually regained herself and began again on the path to normalcy (successfully, I might add); my father did not and died a man broken by cruel, hateful people. Without going into much detail at the moment, my home was hell. Needless to say, my parents never owned a house, did not have a college fund for me and did not provide a stable environment to learn such life skills as say, budgeting or active listening. By 23, I was a self-destructive alcoholic with a mountain of debt and a college degree in a completely bankrupt field (photojournalism). In one week during my 24th year, I was laid off and my father abruptly died. I spent the following six months in a drug-fueled fugue state where I attempted suicide at least twice that I can remember. Yeah, it was bad. I came through it, though, my angel husband, with the patience of a saint, paid my bills and waited with the faith that I'd come back someday. I did come back, and I know the exact moment I re-entered my body. It was the summer of 2010. I was in Hanoi, Vietnam, meeting some children the organization I work for (the 100 Friends Project) was helping, doting on a child dying of untreated brain cancer, too late for us to help. Kien was a gentle, funny creature, completely oblivious to his own impending mortality, and only wanted to play, to be a normal little boy. He treated me with absolute trust. He didn't see that I was broken. In that hospital foyer, my brokenness fell away into sweet oblivion in the embrace of this innocent, dying child. For the first time as far back as I could remember, I didn't want to die. I wanted to be alive and feel this pain and help as many children as possible. (You can learn more about Kien, here, at my old blog. Bring tissues.) Travel gave me myself back. Being in completely alien places gave me the space to drop my guard and feel again, to face my demons alone in a hotel room on the other side of the world, in a slum in Bangkok, at a temple in Cambodia. Having a boss who treats me with kindness and respect instead of as an empty automaton consistently renews my confidence. Picking up my camera after years of disuse and documenting the pain and ecstasy I always hoped to capture saved my life. So here I am in this moment, blinded and sticky like a newly hatched chick, with joy and confidence of the absolute certainty that the worst is behind me, that all that remains is this honeymoon period with myself. I'm learning to accept myself, my flawed nature and my flabby body. I feel I am meeting me for the first time. I hope that along this public journey of self-acceptance, I can help you find your Vietnam, find your Kien, find your moment where you re-enter your body and re-engage with the world, raw and honestly. Life is rich. Life is good. With all it's pain, life is certainly better than the alternative.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: While I would love to bring up my upbringing, I cannot on my own blog since my parents read it and I'd rather not bring up old wounds. Lets just say I was the blacksheep in a Mormon family with a single mother and no college fund as well - to end up graduating with a mountain of debt and a FILM degree (joy). I'm with you lady. Traveling is the only way I can heal my heart. I cannot wait to start my work with the world.

I'm so excited to watch your journey. If during your travels you ever find yourself in want of connections in SE Asia, I can hook you up! I'm rooting for you both! Thanks for being my very first comment and first subscriber. I'm thankful for Twitter and Nick for connecting us.
You gotta love the internet. I've met some of the most fantastic people. Thanks for being our cheerleader!

item.title: Introducing My Passion: Toilets
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_52" align="alignleft" width="220"] I'm about to build a whole lotta these[/caption] Now that I've given you a little introduction to who I am, I want to share with you my excitement for my life's passion, the drive that gets me up the morning, the reason I was put on this Earth: tackling the Global Toilet Crisis. There's a good chance you've never heard of the toilet crisis put in so many words. You've heard about the importance of ensuring access to fresh water. You've been told not to drink the tap water in certain countries. You know that children in the developing world die from "lack of clean water." You've probably supported Operation: Water or others in "getting clean water to people who need it." Those are all vague, PR-friendly ways of saying nearly 50% of the world doesn't have the infrastructure to keep their poo and their drinking/cooking/bathing water separate. America is blessed with some of the highest quality sanitation in the world,  and as such, it can be really difficult to conceive of places that don't have public water treatment facilities, where the poo isn't just flushed away and immediately forgotten. I certainly never thought twice about the ability to drink from the tap before I traveled to Vietnam and Cambodia, where you really shouldn't drink the water if you want to have any sort of pleasant vacation. Since I was paranoid about any contaminated water getting in my mouth or eyes, this is the face I'd make while showering as quickly as possible: [caption id="attachment_41" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Me "washing my face"[/caption] As much of an annoyance as that was (I will never get used to brushing my teeth with bottled water), I am comparatively wealthy: I could simply buy bottled drinking water and point the fancy hotel shower head away from my mouth, thus remaining healthy. The reality for a vast percentage of the world is not so mildly annoying.  Diarrhea is the second leading killer of children in the world, responsible for more childhood deaths a year than Malaria, HIV/AIDS and Tuberculosis combined. Diarrhea causes 1.5 million deaths of children under 5 annually and is responsible for another million deaths of people over age 5. Almost every diarrhea-related death could be prevented through adequate public sanitation. Frankly, viral diarrhea is spread through the consumption of germs expelled in excrement from others who have diarrhea. Hella gross, right? Yeah. If you are too poor to buy bottled water, as much of the developing world is, you are destined to consume contaminated water, every day, for your entire life. This means an unending cycle of illness and the constant lurking threat of death for you and your children, just from consuming the water you need to survive. If you are lucky enough not to die from diarrhea, you still have to contend with continual education interruptions, since constantly sick kids often can't make it to school, lost opportunities due to incomplete education and hundreds, if not thousands, of lost working hours in adulthood on account of caring for direly sick children or having frequent bouts of diarrhea yourself.

Simply put, no community can pull itself out of the cycle of poverty without a basic guarantee of fresh water, impossible without adequate sanitation.

It seems like a cause, a problem too big for us to stop. It IS huge and a bit intimidating, but I do believe that together we can save millions of children from preventable illness and death. All we need are toilets. Well, all we need are toilets, simple sanitation facilities appropriate for a given environment and community public health education programs. I'm starting small. One toilet in one village in one country at a time, learning about different styles of sanitation infrastructure, training community teams to be public health educators and leaving stipends for maintenance and job creation. I want promote a sense of ownership of one's health, no longer dictated by the constant consumption of contaminated water, and I need your help to pursue this mission. In the following weeks, I will explain in depth about the methods of my toilet madness, but in the mean time, please take a gander at our shiny, new donation page (Toilet Equality Project: Cambodia) and spread the word about what we're trying to do. If you're interested to learn more about the global toilet crisis, I urge you to watch this video from Vanguard. It's easily the most comprehensive introduction to the crisis I've found so far. It's 45 minutes long, but absolutely worth your time. Next on The Solar-Powered Yogi: Why Cambodia?

item.title: Why Cambodia (1)?
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
People ask me, "Why Cambodia?" It's absolutely true that you can basically throw a dart at a world map and, if you hit land, there's a 50/50 chance you'll hit a place that needs sanitation infrastructure assistance. Cambodia is one of those places and happens to be a place I've been. There, I have people I know and a network of contacts and resources through my work with the 100 Friends Project. I also happen to love Cambodia more than anywhere I've ever been.
By the time I got to Cambodia, I had been on the road for a couple of weeks, having adjusted to the temperature, time zone and the everyday difference of life in SE Asia. Already, my heart had been opened a little more, my soul a little healed, buoyed by being in Buddhist countries, not being a religious minority. I had already wept at the temple of the Jade Buddha. I had already felt the sting of loss in Kien. I had been in Bangkok right at as the Red Shirt affair reached its most violent head, and where I was in Vietnam, Hanoi, is likely the least tranquil area in the entire country. In short, my trip thus far had not given much room for quiet contemplation.
From the moment our tuk-tuk left the airport in Phnom Penh, everything felt different. There was maybe half the traffic of Hanoi and they were going half as fast. The sun was shining, the smog was minimal. There were flowers on the trees. Everyone smiled. Everything was slower. In that 20 minute drive from the airport to the hotel, I fell in love. Maybe it was the exhaustion, maybe it was the sadness lingering from the children's hospital in Hanoi. Maybe it was just the evening breeze after the oppressive heat and pollution in Hanoi. I don't know why, but in those twenty minutes, my whole life changed. Our driver, Bo, was a good friend of my boss, who I became very close to in the following days. I just sat back and listened as he and my boss laughed and exchanged joke and stories, enjoying the novelty of my first tuk-tuk ride.
Fast-forward about a week, I found myself at a bus stop in Siem Reap after the absolute most nightmarish transportation experience of my life (trust, I'll relay it to you some time), exhausted, queasy, alone, wondering why the hell I decided to go gallivanting off to see Angkor Wat by myself. Never mind that Angkor Wat had been my number dream destination since I was 12, at that moment I thought I seriously needed my head examined. There, waiting in the mud for me, was Bo's friend Lem and his tuk-tuk. He took my bags, helped me deal with a Cambodian bank for the first time, found a hotel for me and was generally my brain for the evening without a thought or question. The next day, he made my dream of seeing Angkor Wat a reality, not just as my driver and tour guide, but as a jovial companion and good conversationalist since I was doing this world-altering thing alone. Lem is whip-smart, though a child of the Khemr Rouge. Had he been born in another place, he could have been a lawyer or a doctor. "

item.title: Why Cambodia?
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Sorry for the delay in getting this post out. A major family crisis arose and it's been a bit trying. Thanks for your patience. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- As promised in my last post, I would like to now delve into my heart for helping Cambodia. People ask me, "Why Cambodia?" It's absolutely true that you can basically throw a dart at a world map and, if you hit land, there's a 50/50 chance you'll hit a place that needs sanitation infrastructure assistance. Cambodia is one of those places. The people who survived the horrors of the Khmer Rouge and the draconian policies of the rulers who followed are now tasked with slowly rebuilding their country and sustainable livelihoods under a new bureaucratic-heavy government that gives not a single shit about caring for the citizens who are not among the disgustingly wealthy few. It's a tourism-wealthy country, making large amounts of money off Western tourists annually, but very little of that wealth trickles down to the people. Traveling throughout that beautiful country, you will see sparkling hotels, imposing government buildings, shining temples for tourist cameras, restoration endeavors at historic destinations like Angkor Wat, and a brand new, fancy boardwalk in Phnom Penh, paid for by foreign countries including the US. Yes, Cambodia is recently shellacked with a shiny veneer so vacationers can be just distracted enough not to notice the seething truth of human suffering barely hidden underneath.

As a tourist in Cambodia, if you put forth the smallest effort to take off the blinders and put on your compassion hat, it is not difficult to see through the facade and get the real story. You may notice that despite the luxury of your hotel, you must drink the complementary bottled water, never from the tap. You may notice the shadowy presence of the extensive slums just out of view from your guided tour. You may notice many very old people and very young people, but a distinct lack of the middle-aged, a subtle reminder of the recent genocide. You may notice the filthy-faced, haunted-eyed children who beg at the tour bus rest stops. You may notice the bullet holes even Angkor Wat could not escape. With these hints of something undulating under the tourist-friendly surface, you may decide to carefully investigate. Maybe you go to the Killing Fields memorial. Maybe you ask your tuk-tuk driver to take you to a temple or a market not on the tour route. Maybe at the historic Foreign Correspondents Club, you strike up a conversation with a weathered white guy who happens to work at the Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity, Action pour les Enfantsor any of the hundreds of other specialized charities in Phnom Penh. Maybe he tells you about the foreign NGOs that fight against sex tourism, domestic violence, child exploitation, hunger, HIV/AIDs and lack of water access where the Cambodian government fails. Now you begin to see; this is a country in crisis.

[caption id="attachment_68" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Children begging at rest stop in Cambodia[/caption] As a Western woman, traveling alone (a novelty), people in Cambodia were very kind to me, at ease enough that many felt compelled to flag me down to tell their stories. (I have no idea if this is a normal experience in Cambodia, if this happens to men or people who travel in groups also, or if it was a unique experience as a solo female traveler.) They were practically bursting to tell me the story of Cambodia, what horrors they witnessed as children under the Khmer Rouge, and warnings of the current government's corruption. I asked each person who did this why they wanted to tell me these very personal, and sometimes legally dangerous, stories and each one said,
"The Cambodian people, we need you to know, we need you to tell everyone in the West about what happened to Cambodia."
Since I was traveling on a mission of mercy, walking unblinking into the heart of suffering, there was no lag time for me to realize the pain these people have survived and how utterly their government has failed to do anything but extort every bit of life blood from their people. I walked through the slums. I went to different orphanages, most of the children being former garbage dump workers and/or orphaned by AIDs. I visited the home of my friend, whose 6-person family lives in a rough shelter smaller than half my living room. Every person I met along the way had either an entire life revolution by someone building them a toilet or would have an extreme improvement of quality of life with that infrastructure. And I can assure you, their government simply will not deign to help their people in such a basic way. It's up to us to bring that change. [caption id="attachment_73" align="aligncenter" width="500"] My friend's children outside their home in Siem Reap, Cambodia[/caption] ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- If you are inspired to help please retweet on Twitter, share this story on Facebook or click here to donate to Toilet Equality Project: Cambodia. Have questions? Please feel free to comment here or email me at solarpoweredyogi@gmail.com

item.title: Travel Hacking Pt. 1
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded: At the moment, I am far above Earth, flying home from a week visiting my family in Indiana, celebrating my little brother's high school graduation and having a traditional Midwestern cookout for Memorial Day. Since travel is one of the most important things I do to refresh myself and recharge my spirit (second only to yoga) and I am a bit of a veteran traveler, clocking over 400 flights so far, I thought it would be a good to time to start sharing my travel hacking tips. Consider this my first installment of many on the topic. I hope you find my suggestions helpful! Let's start with the most basic aspect of air travel, the carry-on. The purpose of the carry-on is not to pack enough to entertain you for the rest of your life, just to sustain you for the flight while considering the possibility of delays or extended layovers. Things I always pack in my carry-on for air travel, domestic or international: [caption id="attachment_82" align="aligncenter" width="500"] What I carry-on (Note: the silver bag in back holds medicine, vitamins, etc)[/caption] -Passport: While obviously necessary for international travel, I've found flashing my passport at any domestic security agent garners more respect and less hassle than your standard state ID. Couple that with an elite flier status with your frequent flier program and you will own the skies (or at least the terminals). -Medicine, medical devices, vitamins, glasses disposable contact lenses: This is pretty obvious. If your checked baggage gets lost or you become delayed, you don't want to be without your medical necessities. Also, pharmaceuticals have a way of mysteriously disappearing from checked luggage. It's not worth the risk to pack them separate. -An LED headlamp: As my husband glibly says, “Headlamps: they're useful when it's dark.” I am often too short to reach the overhead light without bothering my fellow passengers (if at all), so having my own personal lamp is crucial for navigating my stowed luggage, reading and eating on long, dark, overnight flights with minimal irritation to my row-mates and myself. My headlamp has also proven to be infinitely useful in myriad unexpected situations while traveling around the world. For a timely example, when we first arrived in Indiana last week, we were beset by tornadoes which immediately knocked out the electricity for 12 hours that night. With my headlamp, I was able to help my hosts locate their candles and flashlights as well as cook a comforting meal and open bottles of wine, all with hands-free illumination. -Business cards: Since I work for a non-profit and have now started another, I have absolutely no shame in regards to pushing my causes on whomever will listen. I, personally, can't sleep on planes, so if my row-mates are similarly sleep-averse, we will inevitably strike up a conversation. Have your business cards at hand, because new clients, donors, collaborators or friends can be hiding anywhere. -Solid deodorant: The cramped spaces and recycled air on planes have a special way of making everyone funky way quicker than normal. Be kind to your fellow passengers and tone down your personal musk. As someone really freaked out by chemical/aluminum deodorant, I have found a happy compromise with this solid bar from Lush. It's not a liquid or a gel (so no issues for TSA), but just an innocuous block that lasts forever and does the job better than any other all-natural deodorant I've found. See also: clean undies, toothpaste. -Industrial ear plugs, eye mask, iPod with nearly noise-cancellation earbuds: There will be crying babies. There will be loud talkers. There will be really terrible movies flashing brightly in your face. There will be couples heavy-petting right behind you. There will be 8-hour bus rides in 115 degree heat with K-Pop blaring and natives vomiting the entire way. For these special times, you need a fool-proof way to block out the world. Thankfully, we have this technology. -Laptop, cellphone, jewelry, tablet and camera: Another obvious one. Be productive, be entertained and ensure the security of your valuables. Include their chargers in case of extended delays or checked baggage loss. -Religious or spiritual nicknacks or literature: I never start a journey without the tiny Ganesha I picked up in Siem Reap and a copy of the Bhagavad Gita. Whatever your spiritual leanings, be sure to bring along a little something to remind you of yourself, especially when visiting a foreign culture alone. -Enough local currency to get you through the first 24 hours on the ground: Especially after traveling the 24 hours to get to Asia, I arrive in foreign countries starving, exhausted, dehydrated and confused. All I want to do is get to my lodging, stuff my face and sleep, not deal with money-changing and a potential language barrier. In particular, the transit and stuffing my face portions of the day are obnoxious to attempt without local currency already in hand. Yes, I learned this the hard way in both Thailand and Vietnam. Deliriously hungry while functionally broke is no way to start a trip, so stop by your bank before you leave and they will help you prepare. Yep, that's it. I've had many years of practice in trimming my carry-ons to the bare minimum and I've found that any more than this means that I am overwhelmed and annoyed with crap. Another determining factor, as airlines are cramming more seats into tinier spaces to make more money, space for carry-ons is more at a premium than ever before. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I'm very curious to see what other people consider necessities for air travel. Please join the conversation in the comments!

item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
To be honest, I've been really imbalanced recently. Going back "home" for the first time in over a year to mark the most significant family milestone since my dad died really threw me for a loop. Even before the trip though, I was feeling that old, familiar sensation, the sands moving under my feet, the riptide pulling me further from a steady footing. The free and easy peace I cultivated during the feast times of success did not withstand the slings and arrows of the recent famine. To allude to the familiar parable, I built my home upon the sand. I put the weight of my joy on externalities: other people, my environment, my health, my yoga practice, but as each of those became weak or heavily challenged, they buckled under the pressure and I was left with my strongholds crumbling around me.
I must adjust. I must return to basics.
This is not a post telling the world that I've found the magic bullet to making it all better. "Just drink this green smoothie and only eat organic and do Bikram 90 minutes a day and sing this kirtan and march in this edgily-named protest and buy this handbook to throwing away all your shit and donate to this charity and wear these organic hemp yoga pants lined with unicorn hair and THEN you will never lose your tranquility ever again!" No. If there is anything I learned from the past few months is that no convolution of capitalism, no diet, no punishment or self-mortification, nothing you can buy, sell or turn into a mantra will insulate you from pain, loss, confusion and death.

item.title: Fucked Up, Angry and Unashamed
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I'm afraid to write. Not just afraid to publish, but afraid to commit word in a form where I can read back my thoughts. Those horrifying thoughts. Those thoughts I hate to admit are usually me tearing me down, comparing myself to others, hating my body, swallowing society's lies about women, failing my own insane rubric for myself, denying my pain. I was recently forced to relearn that hiding my ugly parts in a dark corner and pretending they don't exist doesn't make them go away. They fester. They bubble up as rotten excreta, spewing forth at inopportune times of extreme stress, when I need to be most on the ball. This happened recently. I hurt people I love. I failed as a person in important relationships. I never want that, but it happens. Part of me is a monster. As painful and embarrassing it is to admit that I am part-monster, it has to be done or else I am a hypocrite. One of my deepest beliefs is that the world desperately needs people, especially strong, influential women, to stand up and say: "I'm fucked up and that's okay!" Those are the role-models we should strive to be. Not "look how perfect I am! You, too, can be perfect if you try really hard and have a lot of money!" If that's the message we're putting out into the world, we're no better than the cosmetic industry, dressed up in hipster, minimalist, all-natural, organic packaging. I'm exhausted. That's right, I am fucking tired. I'm tired of watching people I respect turn into capitalist vampires who believe their own hype and have become so far removed from their faults they forget the multiple falls that brought them to realize their methods in the first place. Mostly, though, I'm tired of this: "Just drink this green smoothie and only eat organic and do Bikram 90 minutes a day and sing this kirtan and march in this edgily-named protest and buy this handbook to throwing away all your shit and go to this influencer event and travel to this exotic land full of noble savages and install this widget and wear these organic hemp yoga pants lined with unicorn hair and THEN you will never lose your cool/your tiny waist/your health/your influence/your happiness/your life." No. If there is anything I learned from the past few months is that no convolution of capitalism, no diet, no punishment or self-mortification, nothing you can buy, sell or turn into a mantra will insulate you from pain, loss, confusion and death.
Anyone who tells you otherwise in earnest is either an idiot or a charlatan.
I have a revolution in mind. One of truth, standing on the roof screaming into the megaphone: I am fucked up and angry! These are legitimate emotions! HULK SMASH EMOTIONAL FRAUD! Look, kid, I'm standing in the world naked, bleeding and screaming. I have no idea what I'm doing. I get angry (really, really angry). I have a mean streak. I drink slightly too much wine. I don't do yoga every day. I can't stick to a diet. I am selfish. I am persnickety. I am judgmental about asinine and pointless things. I can't part with sentimental objects. Part of me still believes my life will be better minus 30 pounds. I care as much about what other people think of me as I did in high school. I am capable of extreme jealousy. I feel stupid every day. I am human, not super-human, cyborg, cylon, post-human, transhuman, rock star or radical anything. I'm just human. These are things I constantly try to hide, but you deserve honesty and I deserve to live with integrity. Instead of the overuse of superlatives to the point of parody, how about we begin again and say, "Hello, human. I am also a human. I am flawed, but I am very good at xyz." Then show us what you're good at. Live your passion honestly, don't just talk about it. Love your friends, but drop the hero worship. Stop undervaluing your strengths and overvaluing others'. To live with integrity is to break the cycle of silence and lies that contributes to a culture of manufactured inadequacy, keeping you unhealthy, broke and sad and preventing you from being the glorious ray of light you are. Shed the shame and come out to play. You are wanted. You are needed.

Just the way you are.

item.title: Health, Dieting and Ahimsa
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Ahimsa: noun, the Buddhist, Hindu and yogic tenant of non-harming, the karmic exhortation to avoid contributing to the suffering of any and all beings, the abhorrence of violence in all forms

I know the exact moment I fell off the health wagon. Almost exactly a year ago, I returned from a month in Asia to immediately develop a horrendous stomach virus that let me only eat dry toast for 15 days. I lost 10 pounds in those 15 days. At times, I thought I was dying. Just as suddenly as it hit, though, it disappeared leaving me vital, but ravenously hungry. I ate everything. Gluten, cheese, ice cream, chips, crackers, copious amounts of sushi, pasta; it all tasted like food had never tasted before, manna to a person starved. I kept telling myself, "Oh, I deserve a few weeks of indulgence, since that bug was so awful"... "Oh, just another week of this"... "Oh, but it's the Fourth of July"... And so it went for months, until I gained all those 10 pounds back and then some. I just kept telling myself that I would work it off, since exercise had never been difficult for me. Unsurprisingly, procrastination and indulgence immediately and viciously bit me in the ass. While traveling around the Fourth of July 2010, I tore one of the largest muscles in my back. I underestimated how badly I had injured myself and tried to just push through the pain, as every coach had ever taught me. I continued forcing myself through my advanced daily yoga sequences, sobbing from the pain, a stupid move that actually tore it further, leaving me basically bed-ridden for a month and essentially hobbled for 6 months. During this time, I basically did not, could not exercise. I couldn't do any asana for 4 months. I had to completely start my yoga over again with the simplest postures. Wheel, serpent, camel and bow postures are still, today, very delicate attempts. I dipped into a severe depression and continued to just eat everything, completely apathetic towards what beings suffered for my food and ignoring both my nutritional needs and my gluten intolerance. To absolutely no shock to anyone, I was sickly, being in a constant "gluten episode" for a year. I also found it harder and harder to tap into my spring of faith. Food was numbing everything, both pain and ecstasy. After this tumultuous year of emotional growth, but physical and spiritual atrophy, I decided that I'd had quite enough. My back is stronger than it's been for a year, I can't use it as an excuse anymore.

I desperately yearn for freedom from these bonds of poisonous food and hypocritical living.

I suppose my "ah-ha!" moment came when I found myself once again unable to get out of bed, hungover, not from alcohol, but from the gluten I had had the night before in the form of fine bread with salty cheese. I said to myself, this is absolute madness, continually poisoning myself on account of flavor and laziness. That was a month ago and I have not had a fleck of gluten on purpose since then. I'm feeling better, but I know that's not enough. I've stopped causing harm to myself with my food, but what of others? For years and years, I've been locked in a debate with myself, which began as just a nagging pinch, a twinge of something being off, and has become a screaming hypocrisy, a resounding, "NO!" in my heart. I am a Buddhist. I've practiced yoga for 13 years. I've been moved by the texts, enthusiastically agreeing with the Buddha's exhortation to his followers to avoid meat, to live Ahimsa. Now the time has come that I can no longer reconcile my burning faith with not being vegan. For too long have I rationalized milk, eggs, fish, lanolin and honey as fine to consume, because "they're not so bad as meat." But here is my truth, what I believe: no animal was put on this earth to be beholden to my gluttony. It is slavery. It is the physical, emotional and often sexual abuse of living beings for my comfort or pleasure, a perversion of nature that I can no longer abide. There is nothing about humans that make us uniquely sovereign that is not also a trait of every sentient thing that crawls, swims, runs or flies. Every being deserves to live free from the tyranny of the privileged, not just humans. To behave in any way that contributes to suffering would make me hypocrite to my own beliefs. (As an aside, I am not an evangelist, nor do I feel compelled to judge anyone else's choices. Each person must live in concert with their own beliefs, not mine.) I know that's a serious, preachy block of text and I hope you're bearing with me. I suppose the point of this post is to make the announcement of a grand life-changing adjustment, along with the explanation for whomever wants to know why. In the following days, I'll be discussing the fun part of this life change: discovering how to thrive on the beautiful vegetables, fruits and grains I already love anyway. I'm excited to experience and live whatever changes occur in my body, heart and grocery bill as I live honestly and authentically: vegan, raw and gluten-free, one degree of separation from the sun. ____________________________________________________________________________ Question for you: What is your take on veganism? How and why do you fuel yourself the way you do?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well said! I am a vegan and completely agree with you that no animal was put on this earth for me to use. For any reason.
Thanks for stopping by and commenting, Debbie. Namaste
just got around to reading this today- YES. :) this makes me feel good to read, and i look forward to more.
Love you, Val. <3

item.title: The Week in Internet Awesomeness
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Can you believe it's already Friday? I certainly can't! Today, I am excited to unveil this new weekly feature: a Friday roundup of the the most inspiring, beautiful, interesting and delicious things I find around the internet each week. My hope is to enrich your life with articles, causes, sites and occasionally products that light me up and inspire, as well as put some links into the world from my friends who are doing amazing things. Enjoy!
  • My friend Erica and her husband Shaun at Over Yonderlust are permanent nomads, currently working on their SCUBA certification in Honduras. Be sure to click through to their gorgeous beach-side photo gallery at the bottom of the post.
  • A feature from Art of Backpacking on the strange and beautiful Yehliu Geopark in Taipei, Taiwan, now on my list of places to visit.
  • A timely article on listening to your body and caring for yourself with compassion by the phenomenal Amber Zuckswerth: Body Over Mind
  • A feat of yoga proficiency that must be seen, Tripod Headstand to Flying Crow by Rebecca Pacheco at OmGal.
  • Check out my new favorite site, Raw on $10 a Day (or Less!) Beautiful photos, simple satisfying raw vegan recipes.
  • My favorite cosmetic company, Lush, just went public with their new campaign to fight shark-finning by raising awareness, supporting activists in the field and raising funds with a new super cute, vegan soap. Please take a moment to learn about their campaign and maybe buy some soap.
  • If you adore your animal companions as much as I do mine, familiarize yourself with this list of common foods that are toxic to cats and/or dogs. I can't the bear the thought of accidentally poisoning my babies, so I'm glad I came across this information.
  • If you are interested in health, wellness, raw/vegan lifestyles or juicing and haven't watched the documentary "Fat, Sick and Nearly Dead," well, get thee to a Netflix! It's funny, inspirational, heartwarming and electric. Watching it helped me come to a much-needed epiphany about how I approach my health and maybe it can help you, too.
[vimeo http://www.vimeo.com/18732737 w=400&h=225]
  • You want some inspiration? Well my friend, Tyler, has just the thing for you: How to Evade to Police, Trick the Military and Climb a Mountain in 11 Days
  • Jodi Ettenberg went to Wadi Rum, Jordan, and if her photo set doesn't take your breath away, you need to check your pulse: Sunset in Wadi Rum, Jordan
That's a good amount of inspiration for this week, don't you think? Until next time, my post-massage raw vegan recovery meal, AKA how I want to eat for every meal indefinitely: [caption id="attachment_110" align="aligncenter" width="500"] A BAS (big-ass salad) with raw, homemade orange-mango-banana-strawberry smoothie[/caption] -Namaste _________________________________________________________________________________ Disclaimer: I received no money for these recommendations and endorsements. These are simply articles/photos/products I find interesting, useful and/or inspiring.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you for the mention lady! <3 Although, now you made me want a salad in a saladless culture.

item.title: Change is in the Air
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Vestiges of summer are hanging on in my little city by the Bay, but the smell of fall and its slight chill in the evening fog, hanging on longer in the mornings, reminds us that the annual cycle is already pitching back away from the sun. Swiftly, the time is coming for soups and stews, sweaters and extra blankets, jack-o-lanterns and twinkle lights, hosting friends and cuddling lovers. For me, the current changes are even more extreme than the gentle tilting of the earth. My husband and I are moving to a new home, a tiny home that will require us to adopt ultra-minimalism, responsibly liberate 90% of our stuff into the universe and finally fully ween from the poisoned teat of blind consumerism. And can I just say, oh my goodness, what a process! I finally got honest with myself and realized that to be a happy, healthy non-nomad I "need" a bed, a yoga mat, my computer, my camera gear, Lush Cosmetics, a small amount of comfortable, versatile, soft clothes and a gloriously well-equipped and functional kitchen. Everything else is an emotional crutch that I get to decide whether is worth taking up the precious tiny space or not. Yes, I GET to sort through my things and downsize at my leisure.
I feel truly privileged and blessed that I have the choice of excess or not.
  The other huge change I touched on earlier in Why I'm Going Vegan is the process of slowly going high-raw vegan, a goal I hope to have fully adjusted to by the time the complicated holiday season comes along. This is a pretty difficult project currently, while I'm living between two places, one with a pristine, functional kitchen, but no cooking gear and the other with all my food and cooking gear, but falling the eff apart. I know this is only temporary (isn't everything?), but it's truly challenging my resolve. What's been a great blessing, though, is the growing interest of three of my dear friends in taking similar journeys with and around me. Their sweet love and compassion towards me and this process, whether it's getting me out of the moving stress to go out for girl-time and vegan fare or cooking an amazing raw vegan meal to share with us on the holiday or tenaciously using her own life as a laboratory for testing change and inspiring, I am truly learning the sweetness of friendship, learning from others and having folks to trust and lean on.

item.title: Occupied
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
I seem to have taken an extremely long hiatus from blogging. I do not apologize, because I've been very busy.
Thinking.
Ruminating.
I have been absolutely transformed by participating in Occupy Oakland. I don't even remember what drew me to it to begin with beyond journalistic curiosity, but I was quickly swept up in the energy of thousands of people dedicating themselves to each other and the hope of a different world being possible, that our futures were up to our making, that we could heal our own communities without outside permission. I watched many people come, hoping to direct that energy towards their pet cause or pet candidate, becoming frustrated, defensive and leaving when they realized this was a tide that could not be manipulated, categorized or co-opted by Move-On.org or Ron Paul. No, this was not the wan, empty, pretend power of changing electoral politics, working within the same toxic system that knows nothing but breaking the backs of the marginalized. This was, and still is, the primal undulation of the screaming, tired masses breaking out of that paradigm, refusing to work any longer for the gain of their oppressors. This was the first gaping sigh of utter defiance.
It started with skirting the issue of camping permits and ignoring the irritating buzz of the mayor's office nit-picking at imagined infractions, while holding teach-ins on anarchism, the history of labor and the Black Panthers literally on the steps of City Hall. Then they smashed our camp to bits in the dead of night, using flash-bangs and tear gas against unarmed campers, including children, the elderly and the homeless. Then we stood en mass allowing ourselves to be gassed over and over, simply refusing to leave until we had our park back. Then Scott Olsen's story saturated the airwaves and the media descended like carrion-eaters. We rebuilt our camp even better, served 1,000+ free meals a day, organized a local general strike and shut down a port. Then they slammed us harder and more organized, destroyed our camp, arrested the clergy and flooded our historic Oak tree. So we camped in the trees and shut down all the major ports on the West Coast.
They started attacking us in small groups, then, picking us off one-by-one, harassing in particular the homeless and Occupy clergy who stuck around the plaza post-occupation. They invoked archaic local laws, making standing under an umbrella illegal and slapping insidious "stay away" notices on individuals at random. Then a group of local black youth took the initiative to begin defending their elders' homes against unjust foreclosures and organized a weekly "Fuck the Police" demonstration against police repression, taking cues from our comrades in Greece and Egypt, training in Black Bloc tactics. Then we were joined by comrades from neighboring occupations, a few thousand strong, to face down riot police and take a vacant building for a community center and housing for our homeless comrades. While we failed in this goal, it required them to arrest over 400 of us that day to keep us from succeeding.
Though my community is slightly fractured at the moment, distracted by the manufactured conflict between supposed "Nonviolent" and "Diversity of Tactics" schools of thinking (a topic for another day) and a lot of folks are taking a moment to recover from the trauma of mass arrest, I still see so much of that original hope. People are grouching at each other, trying to pull each other into the cycle of human drama, because everyone misses the commune and is looking for someone to blame that's smaller than the entire goddamn system.
But all I see is success after success, hope upon hope.
I see hope in the new graffiti in my neighborhood of "DECOLONIZE," "long live the Oakland Commune" and "May 1st General Strike" where once were gang tags. I see hope in people from every type of background imaginable coming out of 30hrs (or 3 days) in Santa Rita closer than family. I see hope in overhearing conversations on anarchism, anticapitalism, alternative schooling, safer spaces and police brutality while walking down the street or riding BART. I see hope in the fact that folks walking down the street smile at each other, find conversation with strangers easier and are recommitting to patronizing hyper-local businesses. I see hope in the openness with which we're all suddenly talking about race and privilege. Even when we fight and have hurt feelings, it's being brought out of the shadows and actually fucking acknowledged, something we desperately need locally and nationally. I see hope in our neighbors hanging out of their windows and cheering, clapping and giving the solidarity fist when the "Fuck the Police" march passes by their homes. I see hope in suddenly having a few hundred people who have my back, who comfort me in my grief and rage, who lend each other their expertise freely, and who give each other food, shelter, clothing, time and money joyfully, with no expectation of repayment.
I see these hopeful murmurings, the bright green shoots of our revolution's early spring and nothing else matters. We have caught the hope and imagination of several generations. We've caught the attention of the world. I know we often won't agree. We will argue and bicker hyper-publicly, in real time. I know we're going to fuck up a lot, because few of us have ever done anything like this before. But the fact that we ARE trying in the face of such staggering evil and we get up again and again and again and again no matter how they brutalize us or try to tear us apart is a victory.
And I am so proud.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I am so proud of you lady! I've been keeping up with the movement through your Tweets and thank you for posting this. If I was at home, I would be in the streets with you.

item.title: J28, or In which I Get Arrested with Occupy Pt.1
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
On January 28, 2012, I decided to celebrate my birthday with some of my dearest friends at Occupy Oakland. It was a gorgeous day, blue skies, unseasonably warm for January. A glorious weekend action was planned, we were going to take over an empty, public-owned building and transform it into a community center and safe place for our homeless brothers and sisters. We were going to re-open the OO kitchen and medical center to get back to doing what we love best: feeding and healing folks in our community outside the constraints of a capitalist system intent on monetizing every human interaction. The plan was to take the building Saturday morning then spend the whole weekend celebrating with our community.
Long story short, riot cops crashed our party immediately. They repeatedly gassed and shot projectiles with abandon into a peaceful crowd with families, small children and the elderly in a residential neighborhood (my neighborhood, actually) in broad daylight. When mothers and caregivers attempted to remove their children from the situation to a safe distance many blocks away, they were followed and menaced by cops who screamed threats of "child endangerment." Dozens of protestors were injured either by projectiles or brutal beatings by police in full riot gear. And if anyone being beaten dared to defend themselves by covering their head or trying to escape? Welcome to felony land. By the end of the day, 409 people were arrested, the second largest mass arrest in California history. I was arrested for my birthday, charged along with most everyone else with "Misdemeanor Failure to Disperse."
I was among the very first people arrested during the evening march. My wrists were zip-tied so tightly, I lost all feeling up to my elbows and had various states of numbness for a week after. We were packed into holding cells at twice to four-times capacity, every holding cell in Santa Rita squeezed full of Occupiers. In some cells, people had to take turns sitting on the toilet, because they were packed in too tightly to sit anywhere else. There was either too little air, or they froze us. There was either no food or packages of room temperature bologna-juice-laden "food" that gave food poisoning to those who risked nibbling. We were denied our medications. The injured were denied medical care, even those with internal bleeding from being beaten or with pre-existing conditions like cancer and epilepsy. At least 3 HIV-Positive Occupiers were denied their anti-retrovirals long enough to risk their lives. We were all covered with tear gas and pepperball residue, which continually reactivated with our moisture and body heat. None of us were ever decontaminated. Male inmates, sheriffs and janitorial staff could easily watch the women in my cell use the toilet. I could continue for many paragraphs on the treatment we received in Santa Rita, but I imagine you get the picture. My group was lucky; we were out after only a day. Many others were there for 3 days or more, without records for their loved ones and lawyers to find them, disappeared without charge or recourse for days.
I refused to eat in jail, both as an act of self-preservation and an act of defiance. I knew any exposure to bologna-contaminated bread or cheese would have me extremely sick, monopolizing the toilet, and after a certain amount of time without my stomach meds, they could have placed a five-star vegan meal in front of me and I still couldn't eat it. At hour 20 of no food and minimal water, things began to get more difficult. I refrained from the various conversations and activities happening around me to beat the boredom and madness (dance teach-ins, yoga, charades, bologna art, etc), saving my strength. By hour 24 of no food, moderate dehydration and a few hours past time to take my medicine, I sat on the bench immersed in my discomfort, desperately wanting pen and paper. By hour 28 without food (30hrs without sleep, 20hrs in custody), dizzy from hunger, sinuses swollen shut, head throbbing from dehydration, body wracked with pain from denial of my daily meds, my only thought was, "This will end. This has to end." I began to cry uncontrollably. Three of my sisters encircled me in their arms and we cried together.
I didn't know where my husband was (he was also arrested). I didn't know when I would get my medication or how long I would be in pain. I didn't know when my cellmate and friend would see her kid again. I didn't know when my cats would run out of food and water at home. I didn't know if anyone outside knew where I was or was searching for me. I didn't know how long I would be trapped in a box without food, sleep, medicine or information. That not knowing, that panic, that confusion, that being at the absolute whim of some faceless, sadistic bureaucrat with a badge, that's jail.
By the end, my priorities had shifted dramatically. I no longer wanted a shower or food or bathroom privacy or even handsoap. The only things in the world I truly wanted were for my pain to stop and to know where my husband was. I would have stayed indefinitely as long as I had my medicine and that information. I felt, and still feel, a coward for that, broken within 24hrs with moderated hunger, sleeplessness and denial of medication and information. That moment of broken confusion and pain made an impression, though. I had been living in a bubble of privilege where I imagined being arrested while protesting in America (as opposed to the experiences of "real criminals") would mean at the very least access to my meds. It was foolish, privileged, internally hierarchical, racist and classist to have fostered that assumption. There are no "real criminals," only human beings reacting to a colossal system of hierarchy and injustice, of haves and have nots. Our treatment on J28 is not somehow more unjust because we were protestors instead of drug dealers or sex workers. All prisoners are political prisoners.
TO BE CONTINUED...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A brand new blog post, just in time for our arraignments: #J28, or In which I Get Arrested with #Occupy Pt.1

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: A Brief Overview of the Prison Industrial Complex | The Solar-Powered Yogi
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] (This the follow-up post to “J28, or In Which I Get Arrested with Occupy”) [...]

Just in case it is not clear to anyone who is olkoing to donate to OSD, I was there since October 5, the march on October 7, I pitched a tent in Freedom Plaza on October 9, and was at the first finance committee meeting and there everyday as it was formed. Pat B., myself, and a few others met everyday at 4 PM for over a month to make that committee something everyone associated with OSD could count (no pun intended) on.You should also know that the very week of 100 years of free speech was marked in The Occupy San Diego GA failed to pass a proposal after at least 3 meetings. At the last meeting the proposal failed to reach 90% consensus. A group of 25 to 40 people became so outraged that they decided to leave Occupy San Diego. This group now meets at Childrens Park and calls itself OSD. It suspended protocol and violated OSD process. In an act of anger and aggression a vote was called and all those who were opposed were physically and verbally intimidated into letting that illegitimate action pass. Those are the facts. Until further notice (the name of this site) is now my place to blog. There are groups of people who have left OSD for many reasons. Many no longer recognize the group in Children's Park as having any authority. Many are planning meetings. I am one of those people. I will be blogging on my experience here on this site.

Starts with your personal itnaerolships fine then what? The math is pretty clear that Statists are out breeding you. If you have a better answer let me know However to me it seems civil disobedience is one of the most effective ways of awaking people to the fact that Government is force. Maybe its different for you but I don't see myself talking to Lockeans who believe in the Social Contract or that force is necessary to establish a free society. What I see is a bunch of people living in a strange delusion that governmental action involves rainbows and lollipops.

that if I'm not willing to go to jail for my ansrchiat beliefs, then I'm a coward. Never mind that my main belief is that I should be around for my children. Apparently children don't matter, except as abstractions whose rights lie somewhere in the future, if anywhere.I just came in from FDR, looking for FDR blogs that are still active. I'm finding a lot that aren't, so I am happy to find one that is. (That being said, I haven't been very successful at keeping one going over the years, either.)

The question of ewhther the relationship between Israel and Palestinians is one of oppression or one of conflict, is a critical question.There is no question in my mind that there are elements of both. To declare that the relationship is only an oppression is to misrepresent what is going on there.There are two ways the issue is not simplistic.One is that as Ralph referred, there is a long long long history of one stimuli (say from 1920), evoking a response (in 1921), which then evokes another response the other way in 1922, etc. ad infinitum, hotter at some times, quieter at others. Everyone says that the other started it.In a circle.The second is of the geography. If one looks at only one scale, Palestine is surrounded by Israel. There are only borders with Israel and Jordan, and Israel jointly controls the Jordan boundaries.But, at a slightly larger scale, Israel is surrounded by Arab states. Until 1979, they were entirely surrounded, and with a great deal of animosity. Now that there are treaties in place with Jordan and Egypt, and cooperation on security with the PA, that logic is diminished. But, at the same time, the experience of Iraq firing missiles at Tel Aviv in the fist Gulf War, even though Israel was not a party to the conflict, adds weight to the importance of Iran being able to repeat that (with either active nuclear missiles in the future, or merely with nuclear waste now)., multiplied by their near-proxy relationship with Hezbollah possessing tens of thousands of large rockets all aimed at Israeli cities as a hostage.The statement that Israel surrounds Palestine is partially true. Not perfectly true, not perfectly false, and the statement that Israel oppresses Palestine is also partially true, not perfectly true, and not perfectly false.How does one change a conflict? (Maybe with intervention to get everyone's attention, but ultimately with mediation, not with revolution.)

I'm ambivalent on the tamter of civil disobedience. One of the more interesting arguments I've heard (a few months ago, not sure where maybe the civil disobedience roundtable): Civil disobedience is an acknowledgment that the state is something other than a violent gang or a collection of thugs. No one promotes civil disobedience against the mob.
