item.title: A Brief Overview of the Prison Industrial Complex
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
(This the follow-up post to "J28, or In Which I Get Arrested with Occupy") "All prisoners are political prisoners," is how we left last time. There's a real possibility that phrase will confound, puzzle or infuriate you. When people imagine a political prisoner they see Nelson Mandela imprisoned for 27 years for opposing apartheid or Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest for 15 years for unifying the Burmese people against the violent junta. However, it is a product of unjust, hierarchical societal conditioning to place "noble" prisoners like these (personal heroes of mine) on pedestals, decrying their treatment while demonizing "bad" prisoners, i.e. the common drug users/dealers, sex workers, illegal immigrants and petty thieves that fill our bloated prison population. All prisoners around the world have been accused and/or convicted of breaking laws, laws made by the extremely powerful with the intent to keep the power centralized to those extremely powerful. This is as true for the Daw Aung Suu's of the world as it is for a homeless Oaklander facing life in prison under California's three strikes law. All prisoners are a product of the same unjust world and a system of capitalism that pits the working classes against each other, criminalizing any attempts to organize together, while a small group of the extremely rich reap the rewards of that struggle and laughs. It is a system where for-profit prisons are a global multi-billion dollar industry where government contracts must guarantee a steady stream of prisoners and the prisons are under no obligation to have humane facilities for those people, not even in supposedly more "civilized" countries like America. Because we are conditioned to think of common prisoners as less than human, the prison system can go on treating prisoners like garbage with impunity. There is no mass outrage. This is a system where a homeless, black mother gets 5 years in prison for falsifying her address to get her son into a better public school, but the bankers who defrauded this entire country for untold sums of money are vacationing on yachts in Aruba doing body shots of Cristal off nubile 18-year-olds. This is a system where the mere existence of people on the wrong side of an arbitrary border can mean they are indefinitely disappeared without recourse or returned to whatever horrible situation they were so desperate to escape from, often to their death. The type of immigration that is illegal is the kind that the extremely rich cannot profit from, therefore they are either disposed of or put into a prison to profit the wealthy. This is a system that denies the disenfranchised mentally ill any access to medication then criminalizes the manifestations of that illness or the attempts to self-medicate the symptoms, risking life in prison under the three-strikes law in California. The fact that the vast majority of us are seething in struggle within the same system of false hierarchies pitting us against each other and the same puppet strings driving us to turn a profit for the extremely wealthy, I feel comfortable claiming that all prisoners are political prisoners. We are all casualties of the same struggle. A lot of people pose the question, "If the Occupy movement started as a response to bank corruption, why has Occupy Oakland turned their rancor towards the prison system/cops?" I think that's a really valid question that merits consideration. The reason why people all over the country and world (not just in Oakland) are turning their attentions to the prison system is that folks are waking up to the intricate web of global oppression. The extremely wealthy get that way by subjugating the most vulnerable people in the world, disproportionately women and non-whites, and simply buy their own prisons, police and governments to pass the laws that criminalize our destitution and extinguish any attempts at organizing against them with our own blood. The bank corruption that keeps them wealthy at our expense while the rest of the world suffers the brunt of a failing global economy, and our government's easy accommodation of that, is one part of that web. So is the excessively brutal policing of poor areas by cops bankrolled by wealthy folks needing to keep the poor from fighting back. So is the vehement opposition to universal healthcare and food equality. My own small experience within the prison system resulted from the legal terror aspect of the global oppression web. The extremely powerful cannot afford hundreds of people from all sorts of communities that are supposed be segregated taking to the streets as one to deny the legitimacy of those in power (which is what happened on January 28). By grossly mistreating us in jail and hanging over us a year of legal uncertainty (the time they to file charges on the arrested at a whim), the possibility of First Amendment chilling stay-away notices and the constant real threat of violence to our bodies, the law-enforcers for the political elite are pulling out all the stops to terrorize us back to fighting and killing each other in the shadows. Political unrest is very bad for their bottom lines. When the workers strike, when the communities begin to work together outside capitalist constraints, when journalists and whistle-blowers dare to risk their lives by bringing the nasty details of our shared oppression into the open, when large groups begin to question the basic conceptual building blocks for their tyranny like "hierarchy," "authority," "consumption," "tradition," "patriarchy," "borders," etc., their grasp on the reigns of our shared oppression and their vast reaches of power becomes ever more tenuous. Their downfall and our true freedom will come. The walls of the prisons will burn and the laws will be turned on the lawmakers. Perhaps it will be through Occupy or perhaps Occupy is merely an important step in the waking up process, but justice will be served. This monolithic system of oppression is unsustainable and will fail, so keep faith. Keep struggling, keep revealing, keep learning and working together, and remember our political prisoners. Challenge the language, beliefs and popular images that facilitate public apathy on prisoner abuse. Fight for freedom from this corrupt system profiting from the confinement, enslavement and torture of human beings.

"Years ago I recognized my kinship with all living beings, and I made up my mind then that I was not one bit better than the meanest on earth. I said then, and I say now, that while there is a lower class, I am in it; and while there is a criminal element, I am of it; and while there is a soul in prison, I am not free."

- Eugene Debs

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: New post from the Solar-Powered Yogi: A Brief Overview of the Prison Industrial Complex

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I challenge the notion that Occupy started as a protest of corrupt banks. As much as I can't stand that "we are the 99%" chant, within it lies the answer to what Occupy is about. It is a vague notion that something isn't fair. That we're in the majority but things aren't going the way the majority wants. That the 99% chant is so critically empty ironically adds to its meaning.
You see, it's not about specific inequities of banking or politics or gentrification. It's about the general notion that shit's not fair. The chant could have just as easily been "We're pissed off!" What we saw when the camps started sprouting up was people who were just angry for various reasons - they had lost their jobs, they had lost their savings, they felt voiceless in a society that trumpeted itself as a defender of democracy, they wanted our soldiers to come home, they wanted our politicians out of their bedrooms, they wanted better food, better medicine, better housing, they wanted the right to live as they saw fit and not as someone told them they had to. What happened with that anger defined each camp. Some camps fell into line with the notion that they were supposed to be about the banks so they moved their money to credit unions, yelled in front of a BoA or a Chase and then went back to their lives feeling vindicated. Some camps became enamored of the idea that they were supposed to be fighting political corruption so they planned trips to DC, went to their local statehouses, yelled about unfair Supreme Court rulings, and then went back to their lives feeling vindicated.
Part of what made Occupy Oakland special was how adamantly it stuck to its guns that we were not about any one thing. Every time a group gained some power and tried to tell us what we were about, we just swiveled and did something new. Shut down the ports? Follow it up with a foreclosure defense. Occupy a city council meeting? Follow it up with and FtP march. The only constant (besides the whiny outsider's voice constantly yelling that we had forgotten why we were here in the first place) was the police. When we fed people, the police showed up. When we gave people shelter, the police showed up. When we marched on the banks, the police showed up. When we went to defend a union, the police showed up. Everywhere we went, the cops were there and ready to try to kill us. That's the real reason it always seems like we're just about police brutality. Phase two of every action is recovering from the police brutality.
I don't think our message has gotten lost. I don't think we've lost focus. I think we need to just stay mad. I think we need to remind people how mad they are or at the very least how mad they deserve to be considering the shitty way they're being treated. Anger is healthy. Anger is the engine which drives change. Anger will win us this war.
¡Ya basta!
P.S. You're welcome for the Debs quote. It's from his amazing speech to the federal court in Cleveland after he was convicted of Sedition in 1918. Full text here (http://www.marxists.org/archive/debs/works/1918/court.htm)
"I am opposing a social order in which it is possible for one man who does absolutely nothing that is useful to amass a fortune of hundreds of millions of dollars, while millions of men and women who work all the days of their lives secure barely enough for a wretched existence.
This order of things cannot always endure. I have registered my protest against it. I recognize the feebleness of my effort, but, fortunately, I am not alone. There are multiplied thousands of others who, like myself, have come to realize that before we may truly enjoy the blessings of civilized life, we must reorganize society upon a mutual and cooperative basis; and to this end we have organized a great economic and political movement that spreads over the face of all the earth." - Eugene Debs from the same speech

Good lord, time traveling zombie Eugene Debs arose from his grave just to explain the roots of the occupy movement and gracefully thank you for bringing attention to his speech in Cleveland!
Thank you, zombie Eugene!
(Seriously though, Mr. Debs, times have changed since 1926, these days it's considered rude to explain what something *really* means over the explanation of a minority, like a queer female. Sometimes we call this "mansplaining". Consider keeping your time traveling antics from going past the 1950s)

It's also apparently rude to take a shit in a crowded elevator, but I'll be damned if I'm giving that up either.
Thank you for responding to my ideas and not just my genitals.

Besides this video, has this person taken any turpices of the wound he received? I have checked his Twitter feed, and seen none. I don't want to say he is faking, but as someone who has followed the Sea Shepherds, I know that some people will openly lie to get their message/cause sympathy. I am reminded of when Paul Watson was shot . Paul has advocated lying to the media in many books because the lie gets the headline and the correction gets a small box on the inside of the paper.

While I would in no way excuse this bhoivaeur, the suddenness of it (and the increasing volume of voices behind the cameraman) make me wonder if he somehow got in the way of someone behind him whom the cop was actually aiming at. A stretch given the distance between the police and anyone else but there's almost always another side to the story.

Why would you side with the police? They have done niothng but abuse their powers since the beginning of all the occupy events, we the people are allowed to have peaceful protests, and by removing that right its only a matter of time before America goes into anarchy.

That cop should be fired and porsecuted for assault. Police are not immune from prosecution for acts of violence that are not at all reasonably related to the performance of their official duties. Shooting that cameraman with a rubber bullet had no possible reasonable nexus to the performance of lawful police duties.

item.title: Redemption: Just a Beignet Away
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_168" align="aligncenter" width="640"] Hard shadows on a hot day in the French Quarter, New Orleans, Louisiana. May 29, 2012. To buy this print, click here.[/caption] New Orleans. Late May. Hazy sun beating down unceasingly, relentless humidity burdening every breath, an occasional breeze from the Mississippi River the only respite, it was the type of day where you pray for a storm to break the heat, but the storm never comes. Out of practice for travel dealings, I had booked my tickets not realizing I was arriving on Memorial Day, not thinking that the tourists would swarm all the way until Tuesday night, drawing out their long weekend for one more sun-scorched, day-drinking bender. Overheated, jet-lagged, disoriented, and overwhelmed, I played at being a professional photographer all that boiling Tuesday (a near-record breaker, it turns out) amidst the wobbling, sweat-stained, drunken zombie hoards in some bizarro-world Disney French Quarter from hell. After a frustrating day of misstep after misstep, including walking all the way to the St. Louis Cemetery #1 only to learn it closed promptly at 3pm, I found I was badly in need of ice water and air conditioning and ducked into a restaurant much-loved by my husband and me on a previous trip. I ordered before noticing it had become a tourist trap with astronomical prices and food almost too salty to eat. I left a little too quickly and nearly face-planted into one of the many vile pools of milky green hell goo to be found in the Quarter on a hot day, the odor of which being some unholy combination of vomit, urine, stale beer, horse shit and assorted rotting garbage. [caption id="attachment_166" align="aligncenter" width="640"] Horse tie-up in the French Quarter, New Orleans, Louisiana. May 29, 2012. To buy this print, click here.[/caption] Unsatisfied, unsteady and food budget now blown for the day, I wandered to the river as the sun began to fall behind Jackson Square. By the Mississippi, I sat on a rock in a foul mood, steaming like a crawdaddy in my own sweat, and I wondered if I had made a mistake. Where was the New Orleans I had fallen in love with post-Katrina 3.5 years ago? Where were the affordable, delicious meals and the Southern hospitality I had been craving? Had any of it ever existed at all? Had the French Quarter always been a hellish theme park ride after too much cotton candy? Brooding and out of place, I walked back down from the riverside and installed myself in an artificially cooled corner of the Café du Monde. A surly, middle-aged waitress took my order and slammed down my plate of three perfectly fluffy, still-steaming, delectably powdered beignets. Crunchy on the outside, airy insides, air-born particles of powdered sugar choking you sweetly on the inhale, no other beignet exists for me in this world than the beignets at Café du Monde. The perfect convergence of flavor and consistency, something of the county fair funnel cakes of my youth with something of fine French pastries at a London patisserie, is only improved by the café’s pervading aroma of decades worth of frying dough and brewing chicory coffee. No matter how badly I had botched my day until this moment, all was forgiven and all was worth it to bring me to this perfect bite of fried dough in powdered sugar with a glass of ice-cold water. I devoured them with no fanfare and slowly put myself back together, dusted the fallen powdered off my clothes and made my way out the door into the night. [caption id="attachment_170" align="aligncenter" width="640"] Order of beignets at Cafe du Monde, French Quarter, New Orleans, Louisiana. May 29, 2012[/caption] Night falls suddenly in the Quarter, not much in the way of a sunset, just the sun falling behind the cathedral in a haze and the sky going from yellow to lavender to gray to black, but you can feel the sun leaving, its weighty presence quietly receding, letting the world breathe again. The breeze off the river picks up and the whole French Quarter lets out its breath at once, coming alive with music. Passing by dozens of bars and blues joints, with live soulful music at every one, I walked to my streetcar stop, taking in the sweet sounds seemingly suspended in the humid air. Living as near as I do to San Francisco, the streetcars don’t appeal much to me from a tourist standpoint, they aren’t novel or foreign, but are simply beautiful, familiar and the most comfortable means of travel after the heat of the day. With its warm lighting, wooden seats and open windows to let in the cool night breezes and the sounds and smells of a vibrant musical city, I can think of no better way to end a day, especially a bad day, in New Orleans than the historic open-air streetcars. The hour back to my little rented studio gave me time to think, time to breathe, time to literally cool my head and take in all the beauty that made me love New Orleans in the first place. The buzz of the cicadas, the blues, the holy trinity of French cuisine wafting out of every restaurant, the friendly people, the breathtaking architecture and lush gardens exploding in green from every yard; these are the reasons I loved New Orleans once and why it was easy to let my rough, hot day slide away, and focus on licking the powered sugar residue from my lips, lulled into absolute peace by the gentle rocking of the streetcar. [caption id="attachment_172" align="aligncenter" width="640"] View from the back of a streetcar at night, New Orleans, Louisiana. May 30, 2012. To buy this print, click here.[/caption] __________________________________________________________________________ I was not compensated/sponsored for opinions expressed in this post. All photos on this blog are property of Grace Breedlove Photography unless otherwise stated. All rights reserved.

Thank you! I hope you have a wonderful trip! If you have a chance, take a streetcar from the French Quarter into the Garden District. It's cheap, beautiful, relaxing and totally worth the time.

item.title: Weekly Round-Up of Internet Awesomeness
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
I hope you're having an awesome weekend! Here's a collection of interesting, inspiring, informative and beautiful links from the past week. I hope you enjoy them as much as I did.
  • A long read from my friend Tyler at Advanced Riskology on running a marathon on the Great Wall of China. Tons of photos!
  • Mouth-watering pictures of "9 Massively Tasty Thai Fish Dishes" from The Planet D that are making me yearn for Thailand again. There's nothing like real Thai food. Nothing.
  • Here's a recipe for delectable chive biscuits from Melissa, a friend I've known since elementary school, at Bless This Mess.
  • An extremely informative post about the frequent strikes ("bandas") in Nepal and how to deal with them as a traveler by Dave at The Longest Way Home.
  • Go fossil hunting along the English coast with Art of Backpacking.
  • A personal post full of gorgeous photos from long-term traveler Jodi at Legal Nomads about spending quiet summer days at home in Quebec.
All the best for an exciting week ahead! ~Grace

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Well Hey, thanks for a shout-out. I feel flattered, and those biscuits are worth shouting about. Take care!
Thanks for sharing, Grace!
You're welcome! I always love to read about your travels.
You're so welcome! I adore your blog and I'm so impressed with what you're doing. <3

  • While Japan has the reputation of being outrageously expensive, Nomadic Matt proves that it can be done (and enjoyed!) on a manageable budget.
All My Best, ~Grace

item.title: A Different Side of New Orleans
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded: This time around in New Orleans, I stayed a bit off the beaten track, choosing to rent a small apartment in the Carrollton District for the week. I wanted a quiet place to work and have my own kitchen. The Carrollton District was just the right speed for my quiet, solo, working trip. For a first-timer in New Orleans, I definitely recommend staying in the French Quarter and taking advantage of everything the proximity has to offer, but if you visit again (and you will), I advise exploring every side of the Big Easy by staying in Carrollton or the Garden District. Lush, beautiful, quiet and slower-paced, there is the recipe for real relaxation and an authentic travel experience. I spent a lot of my days shooting in the French Quarter, but between the good food, lush greenery exploding from every yard and prolonged bouts of absolute silence, Carrollton started to feel like home pretty quickly. A short walk from my apartment on rough sidewalks is a stop for the streetcar and several excellent food choices, lighter fare than found closer to the French Quarter, perfect for the record-breaking heat. [caption id="attachment_237" align="aligncenter" width="682"] A gorgeous home in the Carrollton District, New Orleans, LA. June 1, 2012 (click photos for larger versions)[/caption] [caption id="attachment_242" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Historic streetcar in the Carrollton District, New Orleans, LA. June 1, 2012. If you'd like a print of this photo, click here.[/caption] Two Carrollton area restaurants proved themselves to be solid, affordable noshing, so much so that I visited each twice; a Mediterranean place called Lebanon’s Café and a breakfast joint called Oak Street Café. Oak Street Café was responsible for the best meal of my entire trip, not because it was anything special, but because it was simple and ordinary, done to perfection: two fluffy eggs scrambled, creamy grits neither lumpy nor sticky, a from-scratch biscuit sliced with the face lightly griddle-fried and a perfect cup of coffee. Live piano and upright bass eased me awake while I sipped my rich coffee and people-watched. Folks who were all obviously regulars chatted across tables, politely including me in their early morning conversations. In that moment, with simple, wholesome food and kind people, I felt the first instance of absolute travel bliss on my trip, where not a single thing was wrong and nothing was broken, where I was exactly where I was meant to be and no force on Earth could compel me to desire anything else. [caption id="attachment_238" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Perfect breakfast at Oak Street Cafe, New Orleans, LA. June 1, 2012[/caption] [caption id="attachment_241" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Vegetarian sampler at Lebanon's Cafe, New Orleans, LA. May 31, 2012[/caption] Only 3 doors down from my tiny studio sits the Carrollton Cemetery, not so well-known as other New Orleans cemeteries, but a historical and photographic site in it’s own right. On the day I had set aside to photograph the Garden District, a major storm system passed through so I spent the day photographing the cemetery between heavy downpours. The results were spectacular. [caption id="attachment_239" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] A storm brewing over Carrollton Cemetery, New Orleans, LA. May 31, 2012. If you'd like to buy a print of this photo, click here.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_245" align="aligncenter" width="682"] Carrollton Cemetery before the storm, New Orleans, LA. May 31, 2012[/caption] [caption id="attachment_240" align="aligncenter" width="682"] Grave statue at Carrollton Cemetery, New Orleans, LA. May 31, 2012. If you'd like to buy a print of this photo, click here.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_248" align="aligncenter" width="682"] Carrollton Cemetery after the storm, New Orleans, LA. May 31, 2012. If you'd like a print of this photo, click here.[/caption] Upon arriving in my sleepy temporary neighborhood, the shadow of Hurricane Katrina is immediately evident. In stark contrast with the stately manors on South Carrollton Ave. are the still washed-out sidewalks and homes bearing the marks of search and rescue just off the main thoroughfare. The government may have forgotten New Orleans, the tourist areas may have whitewashed over the damage from Katrina to put forth a more pleasing image, but explore only a little beyond the tours and day-drinking and you’ll wander into the realm of real life. I don’t know if preserving the search and rescue markers is a statement by owners of the particular homes I saw, but the message was clear to me: “We are here, not for your comfort or touristy amusement, but THIS happened to us and we’re not going away.” Being faced with the stark remnants of one of the darkest episodes in our nation’s history was startling but necessary. As awesome as Mardi Gras, Jazz Fest and all the tourist attractions are, the truth is that New Orleans is a place of immensely strong and kind people with a tragic and difficult history. New Orleans is not a foreign country, as much as it might seem like it at times, it is as American as New York City and the Midwest; the tragic and magnificent history of New Orleans is a part of every American. We owe it to ourselves and the people who lived it to face that history with open eyes, to acknowledge and learn from that painful past. [caption id="attachment_247" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Search and rescue symbols still visible on a home in the Carrollton District, New Orleans, LA. June 1, 2012[/caption] __________________________________________________________________________ I was not compensated/sponsored for opinions expressed in this post. item.title: What I Did On My Summer Vacation
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
This summer has carried me off; the fact that September is right around the corner is shocking! The day in and day out of pursuing fitness, plunging into urban homesteading, helping my nephew have an awesome summer learning to trek and swim and recommitting to my Buddhism practice has produced for me a sort of timelessness, not that I’ve lost time but that linear time has ceased to exist. I am in a sort of joyfully simple cycle of waking and doing what I love, though nothing extravagant or outrageous, just simple work and expansion helping me get clear about my goals. This is a season of family coming first and learning to find joy in responsibility, in the banalities of homemaking and community building. (As always, click on the photos so see larger versions.) [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] My nephew leads a hike in the woods near Lake Chabot, San Leandro, CA. August 4, 2012[/caption]

 Early in the year, in the aftermath of my birthday arrest while marching in the streets for a more just society, the necessity of putting my own health and house in order was made painfully clear. I had never felt so helpless, not being healthy or conscious enough to run, jump a fence or help anyone else then trapped in a box, quickly broken mentally and physically. My now all-encompassing goal is to never feel that helpless again. The most logical way for me to approach rebuilding my life and finding my health again was to make exercise and healthful eating a priority, getting back to basics to heal my crippling sciatica and to control my depression and PCOS as naturally as possible. I had been toying with fitness since the New Year, but in that jail cell, it stopped being about weight loss and started being about freedom.

[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] Poppies in a field of dry grass at a summit near Lak Chabot, San Leandro, CA. July 28, 2012[/caption]

 A wonderful aspect of life I can’t begin to find explanation for is the exponential effect that our efforts have, whether positive efforts in our lives or negative. The more I work out the more I want to work out and the more I want to try more challenging types of exercises. Things I couldn’t dream of attempting a year ago are now reasonable goals for my body and I’m thrilled. The more vegetables I eat, the less I want to eat processed food. The more time I need to accommodate my goals, the more my days expand to fit my needs. There is an abundance in this universe that’s waiting to manifest itself to each of us, we just have to make the decision to start, to build, to act, to put in the work.

[caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] A hazy view over Lake Chabot, San Leandro, CA. August 4, 2012[/caption] The work I do daily to prepare my body and mind for the challenges ahead is not a magic bullet or a special pill, it’s a lifestyle choice involving dedication and sacrifice in enough moderation to make it sustainable for the rest of my time on this plane. Always in the back of my mind is the belief that a time will come, sooner rather than later, when capitalism will take its final gasp, society as we know it will fall, there will be no outside nanny state to feed, medicate, police, think for, or numb us (or deal with our raw sewage), and we will need to rely on the skills we build and practice now to survive then thrive then build a new and better world. The daily work is the prayer, the hope in radical self-reliance to be able to live and never be helpless. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] A bird surveys the South Bay from a peak near Lake Chabot, San Leandro, CA. July 28, 2012[/caption] The activities that speak to this desire for radical self-reliance are many hours a week of cardio, strength-training, Pilates, yoga and hiking, preparing and eating local seasonal foods simply, re-learning food preservation and herbalism, building relationships with people who share my apocalyptic fervor, brushing up on the survivalist skills I learned when I was child in rural Indiana and preparing my mind with meditation and contemplation. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] An unusual light summer rain on Lake Chabot, San Leandro, CA. August 4, 2012[/caption] There is peace in preparedness, peace in caring for your family and community, an overwhelming peace. What I was searching for in my obsession with travel was peace in seeking challenges away somewhere, “othering” the whole world. That hunger to dominate challenges has not changed, but the nature of the challenges has. I have mountains before me, both figuratively and literally, and I wake up each day to face them without the fear that had dominated my life until I walked out of the Santa Rita Jail. The world has never been more beautiful. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="1014"] A bumblebee enjoys a thistle flower near Lake Chabot, San Leandro, CA. July 28, 2012. To buy a print of this photo, click here.[/caption]

What can I do to help you face your fears and, in the words of Kerouac, climb that goddamn mountain?

__________________________________________________________________________ All photos on this blog are property of Grace Breedlove Photography unless otherwise stated. All rights reserved.

this is a brilliant post. i've always been kind of mentally preparing myself for the "end of it all", which as i've stated since i was in junior high, won't be the fire and brimstone that most people see as the apocalypse, but the end of "comfortable civilization" as we know it. where everything goes back to basics and only those with the cunning and savvy to get by will. so since a very early age, i have been into survivalism, living off the land, growing, processing and cooking my own food (simply and with real ingredients that aren't Frankenstein'ed out of a lab). basic animal husbandry (some day, we will own a place where i can have chickens, goats and bees) to provide us with nourishment, foraging, herbalism (mad props to herbalism always!), and the like. a big part of my motivation when working out is the goal of "functional strength", i.e. the ability to save my ass if need be, or to be able to pick up and carry a fallen family member or friend. it's so i can teach my daughter how to be an amazing, strong person and to be able to survive anything life throws at her.
man, i could go on and on. sorry for rambling so much in this small space, but you really hit on a lot of things that have long been near and dear to my psyche, and shaped me into the person i am now. next time you visit, i foresee a lot of long talks between the two of us!

Ramble on, please! (LOL, Led Zeppelin) I really want more conversation and community involvement on this blog, because, IMO, we need to be talking and sharing our strengths with each other globally. "Functional Strength" is a perfect description for what I'm training for. Do you mind if I steal it?

love Led Zeppelin!
well, i certainly will from here on out. it's nice to have someone to bounce these kind of things off of, especially, like i said, it's something important to me and my peace of mind. :)

item.title: "Do not stand at my grave and weep..."
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
Do not stand at my grave and weep, I am not there; I do not sleep. I am a thousand winds that blow, I am the diamond glints on snow, I am the sun on ripened grain, I am the gentle autumn rain. When you awaken in the morning’s hush, I am the swift uplifting rush of quiet birds in circling flight. I am the soft star-shine at night. Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there; I did not die. -Mary Frye, 1938
Death is a natural part of this life, arguably the most natural thing there is, and in my studies of science and metaphysics, I work constantly to accept the process of death as this natural thing. Acceptance of and peace with death, I think, is one of our main purposes in this life, to come to grip with separation and loss as the living and ultimately to release the fear that surrounds our own looming mortality. That acceptance does not come easily and that peace is hard won, though. To walk this earth means to lose over and over and over again. I am among countless thousands to whom Mary Frye’s poem has given comfort in dark hours. Every time I suffer a loss, her words bubble up in my mind to remind me in my grief what I have already known: the dead are not truly gone as long as they are loved. They linger on in the tender moments of daily existence and in our communal storytelling. Once the pain recedes, the dead are allowed to reside in our quiet joys and in those moments, the missing are not missing and the tears are no longer of grief, but of gratitude for that relationship that is not gone, only altered. I grieve that I did not get to meet my little cousin Marco before he died two weeks ago after only a month on Earth. I grieve every day that my father died before we could make a peace with each other. I grieve that there is nothing on this earth that can bring back the loved ones taken by murder. I grieve for my friend who died of cancer when she was still a teenager. I grieve especially for the friends who have died from suicide and hope that they somehow found peace. But every single day there are beautiful reminders of them. When the buildings downtown glitter a certain way at sunset or the fog rolls over the bay in a sudden gust, when I cuddle my kitties or teach my nephew about plants, when I scatter a bit of my dad’s ashes in every new country I visit or when I get up in the morning with resolve not to let my depression stop me from following my dreams, my beloved dead are there. I carry my dead gently in my heart and feel the pain from that separation but also gratitude and joy at having had my life shaped by each precious one of them. I do not stand at their graves and cry. They are not there; they did not die. [caption id="attachment_330" align="aligncenter" width="523"] The peaceful Willamette River at sunset, Portland, OR. Grace Breedlove Photography. September 18, 2012. To buy a print of this photo, click here.[/caption]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "Do not stand at my grave and weep..." After a long writer's block, here's a new post on our constant struggle in dealing with death.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank you for this. I’ve not heard those sweet words and I loved them. We buried our sweet nephew, who happened to be a twin, who lived for only 6 hours this summer. I’m sending this on to his momma. I know she’ll love it too.

I've read this post five times over now. Today would have been the 33rd birthday for one of my closest friends, had she not passed from this world five years ago. At her funeral, her husband and brother read the grief poem, alternating lines. You have no idea how much it meant to me, randomly seeing this on my timeline. Thank you so much.
this was a beautiful post. i've been thinking a lot about mortality lately (always do as autumn starts it's slow death into winter), so this came at a fitting time.

Beautiful Grace. Brought tears to my eyes. I am constantly reminded of those that have passed before me. Subtle nuances that sweetly remind me that they are still with me, their spirit forever living in my mind and soul. I send you love and light for your grieving to shift when it is ready, so that the darkness may lift a little and the light can come in. Big love to you and your sweet nephew.

I've gotten several requests over the past few months for the ability to buy prints and I'm pleased to announced that it can now be done through my new Etsy shop: Grace Breedlove Photos. Most of the photos I've posted on this blog are now available for purchase. If you don't see the print you're looking for, please comment on the post in which it appears. item.title: What Pilates Teaches Me About Yoga (and Life)
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi

item.title: A Season for All Things
item.dc:creator: solarpoweredyogi
item.content:encoded:
It has been my season for grief for several years, the world tearing at my soul, rending me open to learn and feel and grow with each loved one taken from this plane, the separation temporary until I join them beyond. Each death, each passing on teaches me the temporality of this state, the painful brevity of this corporeal experience. I weep as I watch us waste this incarnation on the cycle of human drama, ground into dust in the gears of a sick civilization, poisoning our interactions, making us forget we are transcendent. We are more than our buying power, our education, our tax brackets. We are more than these bodies; we are the children of stars, we are spirit and heat, perpetually expanding in tandem with our unfathomable universe. Separation is an illusion, a lie to keep us from rising up together in reclamation of the ecstasy that is our birthright. I want to live the legacy of my beloved dead and be a testament to the lessons they have left me with. Some days my knees buckle under the humbling reality that I remain when so many greater have moved on. I am an inadequate stand-in for their glory, but in their memory I recommit each day to their exhortations to heal the wounds of the world and ease the suffering of all beings. This life is perilously short. Is there any experience we've had that convinces us otherwise? We know there is no time to waste. Run towards life, hungry for knowledge and fearless with your brothers and sisters on this plane while we can. Let us shed the drama and machinations that fail to serve our spiritual hunger for connection, for the yoking with fellow celestial beings as equals in our ecstatic work. Let our greatness together be boundless.

This post, my work and my life are dedicated in loving memory to my grandfather, William R. Muirhead, who left this plane on January 25, 2013.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Some thoughts I've had since my grandfather's passing: "A Season for All Things"
